channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Raymond Weil, Whose Swiss Watches Told More Than Time, Dies at 87
item.description: Mr. Weil started his watch company at a time when most Swiss watchmakers were going bust, and he helped redefine the nation’s signature product.
item.dc:creator: By PAUL VITELLO

item.title: New Opposition Alliance Founders in South Africa
item.description: Within a week, the merger of two opposition groups that was depicted as a “game changer” that would end racial politics has collapsed amid mutual recriminations.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: Al Qaeda Says It Has Broken Ties With Syrian Affiliate
item.description: The Qaeda leadership said it was no longer connected to the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria, which has asserted an increasingly important role in the Syrian conflict.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Al Qaeda Says It Has Broken Ties With Syrian Affiliate
item.description: An announcement from Al Qaeda’s leadership posted on jihadist websites said it is no longer associated with the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Corruption Costs European Union 120 Billion Euros a Year, Study Finds
item.description: More than three-quarters of citizens believe that graft is widespread in their countries, the European Commission said in a report.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID JOLLY
item.media:description: Cecilia Malmstrom, the European commissioner for home affairs, said corruption "hurts the European economy and deprives states of much-needed tax revenue."

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: February 3
item.description: Disabled men and women demonstrating at a rally at India Gate in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Mandela Left $4 Million Estate to Family, Staff and A.N.C.
item.description: Nelson Mandela’s will is expected to set off another round of squabbling among his family members over his financial legacy.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Car Bombings in Iraq Kill at Least 23 People
item.description: No group immediately claimed responsibility for the attacks but coordinated bombings bear the hallmarks of Al Qaeda’s affiliate in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Student Kills 2 at Moscow School
item.description: A police officer and a teacher were killed when the student opened fire without explanation.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: India Ink: India’s 1st Monorail Opens in Mumbai to Much Fanfare and Doubt
item.description: Mumbai’s development agency touted the much-delayed monorail as a solution to the city’s notorious traffic congestion, but urban transportation experts say the $431 million project is not likely to be worth it.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: The Mumbai Monorail train running between the city's eastern suburbs of Wadala and Chembur on Wednesday.

item.title: India Ink: For Just a Few Rupees, Mumbai Residents Ride a Symbol of Modern India
item.description: Thousands of people swarmed to India’s first monorail on the day it opened to the public, celebrating a major technological advance for the country.
item.dc:creator: By MANSI CHOKSI
item.media:description: People exiting at the Chembur station in Mumbai, Maharashtra, on Sunday after having a ride on the monorail train.

item.title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Reunions
item.description: The border talks with South Korea this week will discuss arrangements for reunions where relatives separated by the Korean War would meet for the first time in six decades.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: North Korea Agrees to Talks on Reunions
item.description: The border talks with South Korea this week will discuss arrangements for reunions where relatives separated by the Korean War would meet for the first time in six decades.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: El Salvador and Costa Rica Hold Presidential Elections
item.description: Both elections were expected to be closely fought contests that focused less on ideology than on unease over unemployment, corruption and crime.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: A voter checked his polling location on Sunday in Panchimalco, El Salvador, on the outskirts of the capital. Left-leaning candidates either led or surged in late polls both there and in Costa Rica.

item.title: News Giant in Japan Seen as Being Compromised
item.description: NHK is under criticism amid signs it is hewing to an agenda approved by the rightist government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:credit: Kosuke Okahara for The New York Times
item.media:description: NHK’s Tokyo newsroom. After several resignations, the broadcaster has been accused of pushing a pro-government agenda.

item.title: Libya’s Cache of Toxic Arms All Destroyed
item.description: The United States and Libya in the past three months have discreetly destroyed what both sides say were the remnants of Col. Muammar al-Qaddafi’s arsenal of chemical arms.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: By ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: In an image from the Pentagon, a bomb was moved from a bunker in Libya to be later drained of its chemical agent.

item.title: Memo From Kiev: As Ukraine’s President Returns From Leave, His Options Seem Dismal
item.description: President Viktor F. Yanukovych may need to choose between empowering his opponents or harshly suppressing them.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Riot police officers stand guard on Sunday outside Independence Square in Kiev. Opposition protests have entered a third month.

item.title: Tamils’ Smuggling Journey to U.S. Leads to Longer Ordeal: 3 Years of Detention
item.description: Experts said the Sri Lankans’ saga shows the subjective nature of immigration enforcement and raises questions about how refugees who cooperate in human trafficking cases are treated.
item.dc:creator: By FRANCES ROBLES
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Tamil detainee at an immigration jail in Miami. He and four others who fled Sri Lanka in 2010 are still waiting for their cases to be resolved.

item.title: Syria Hits Areas Held by Rebels in Aleppo
item.description: Makeshift bombs were dropped across the south and east of the country’s largest city, killing at least three dozen people, most of them women and children, antigovernment activists said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:description: Residents and activists aided a girl who survived amid debris in Aleppo on Sunday after what activists said was an aerial attack that dropped explosive barrels.

item.title: Imax Faces a Threat in China
item.description: Not only could competitors in China cut into its potential market share there, but Imax has charged in several courts that the Chinese system relies on technology that was blatantly stolen from its offices in Canada.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: A screening of a 3-D Imax movie in Beijing. Imax has accused Chinese companies of using misappropriated technology.

item.title: Kerry and Iran Minister Confer on Nuclear Issue
item.description: Foreign Minister Mohammad Javad Zarif said Iran wanted to negotiate seriously, and he offered to begin a dialogue on human rights issues with the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Sudan Tells Red Cross to Halt Work
item.description: The government determined that the group, which helps more than a million people in Sudan, had not fulfilled unspecified conditions for its aid efforts, the state-run news agency said.
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH

item.title: Palestinian Leader Seeks NATO Force in Future State
item.description: Palestine, President Mahmoud Abbas said, would not have its own army, only a police force, so the NATO mission would prevent the weapons smuggling and terrorism that Israel fears.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority said that a new Palestinian state would not have an army, leaving NATO in charge of security.

item.title: Death Toll Climbs After Major Volcanic Eruption in Indonesia
item.description: Toxic clouds of hot ash hampered teams searching for survivors from Saturday’s eruption at Mount Sinabung, which killed at least 15 people.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE

item.title: Airline Sets Deadline on Talks With Alitalia
item.description: Etihad Airways of Abu Dhabi says its discussions with Alitalia over a possible investment in the troubled Italian airline have entered “the final phase.”
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
